posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: ITT: Ask the opposite gender anything
posts.com:
RULES:
Before you ask, see if it's covered by the FAQ.
Keep questions concise. Use paragraphs.
If you can't handle upsetting replies (or the FAQ) don't ask. You will be bullied out of this thread if you act salty.

FAQ:
>What do girls/guys think about <any trait, such as looks, physical or personality traits, virginity, penis traits, or lack of dating experience>?
>Do <most/any> <girls/guys> like <an insecurity over the above>?
There is no one answer, but complexes are always a turn-off.

>I'm shy and afraid of <people/rejection>.
Get over it by practicing and exposing yourself to it bit by bit. There is no "magic moment" (or activity) that will instantly change you.

>I like someone. What do I do?
>How can I tell if someone likes me?
Ask them out. "Signs" of attraction are useless.

>Where do I meet people for <dating/friendship>?
Anywhere outside. Or online. Above all, leave your comfort zone.

>Someone did something insignificant. What does it mean?
Nothing significant. You're overthinking it.

>XYZ happened. What does it mean?
We're not in their head, we don't know.

>Someone has made it clear they're not interested. Do I have a chance?
No.

>Where do I go on a first (or subsequent) date?
Coffee is the preferred first date, but any of the following may work: lunch, dinner, drinks, ice cream, froyo, movies, zoo, aquarium, museum, gallery, park, <activity in your city>.

>I'm insecure because of my <small/avg/big/cut/uncut/phimotic> penis
>Do women prefer penises of certain qualities?
>How do I <use/compensate for> my <as above> penis?
><any question/claim about penises>
Fuck off

>Why can't <women/men> just give a straightforward rejection?!
>Why are <women/men> terrible? <example of conduct>. <claim that most women/men do this>.
Fuck off

><online dating platform> is only for hookups, don't go there for real people!
Fuck off

><thread subject autism>
><anti-FAQ autism>
Fuck off

>Why is there no new thread?
Make it yourself! Try these macros: imgur.com/a/y6BF2

posts.com: When do girls 19-23 expect to have sex?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I quit this waiter job I had about a month ago where I met this adorable waitress. Before leaving I managed to follow her on Instagram, albeit I didn't ask her for her handle and just followed her, I figured it's not so weird to do that because a lot of people I know do so.
FW a month later I decide it's safe to shoot a text asking if she would be interested in seeing a movie in excuse that it's been a while since I last saw her. She said she'd get back to me because she was busy that week with a school event. It's now the week after and I haven't gotten a response. She's definitely aware of my existence because I do post on my story casually.

Did I fuck up, should I just abort or keep waiting, she seemed so compatible and it's breaking my heart.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21519779
For the record I'm 26 but did not feel differently at these ages. It matters on how well I know them, essentially >>21519841.

If I wind up dating a man I've known and been comfortable with for years, I'd expect sex to happen very fast, maybe even right after confessing mutual feelings.

If I start dating a man who cold approached me and I had no shared history with, was still very much getting to know as a person, a handful of dates and a week or two would be the very least I'd need to relax a little and feel ready to open up. Preferably longer.

There's a lot in between these scenarios. And it will depend on her prior experiences, her ideas about sex, you name it.

Not a guy but assuming these classmates are 18-22 I strongly doubt most of them are already thinking of whether they consider the girl they have a thing with wife material, unless you live in a very conservative area. Apparently they find you attractive if they make moves. Younger girls are adorable and lovely but can also be insecure, prissy and fickle - as can young guys, for that matter! - and I'm pretty sure you could score points if you are more forward, more mellow, more at ease with yourself. Lots of inexperienced guys fantasize about a girl who shows them the ropes and lets them come out of their shell and have fun, you are in the prime position to be that person for someone.

Having said that apart from anything else the other anon was right about your attitude. A defeatist feeling that you're only good for x or y very easily becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy (and you are already kind of fucking yourself over by on principle turning interested men down). Work on that. You can't change your age and shouldn't want to, you can change your perception of yourself. It sounds like you have not quite grieved through/processed all the feelings from negative experiences. Try focusing on that. Best of luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21520099
If I don't get a coffee date in the first two conversations, I deprioritize the girl and focus on other matches. I don't unmatch, nor do I tell her off, but I do back down on contact because odds are it's not going to happen.

Remember, the whole point of the chat feature (and other modes of chat, including text and voice calls) in online dating is to accomplish a few very basic tasks: (1) verify you're not a bot, (2) preliminarily verify that you're not catfishing as the opposite sex, (3) verify that you're not psychotic, (4) verify that you have similar goals, and—most importantly—(5) arrange a face-to-face in-person meeting at a coffeehouse.

If you're using chat, texting, voice calls, etc. for ANYTHING other than those tasks, you're doing something very wrong and will almost certainly waste a great deal of time focusing on a small number of people who will never work out. By staying at it for a whole week, you're effectively nullifying all the advantages online dating gives over traditional dating.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21520121
>If I don't get a coffee date in the first two conversations, I deprioritize the girl and focus on other matches. I don't unmatch, nor do I tell her off, but I do back down on contact because odds are it's not going to happen.
I should also be clear: If I were to wind up in the situation you're in, where I clearly asked for a coffee date and the girl balked for any reason (especially being nervous or wanting to "know me better" first), I'd know she wasn't serious or very interested in me and would deprioritize.

The whole point of the coffee date is to get to know the other person. Claiming you want to know someone before you go on a coffee date is like saying you'll only have sex with people you've had sex with before. It either demonstrates that the girl has a fundamental misunderstanding of dating, has a severe anxiety disorder that would probably make any relationship fail, or that she's just not interested and is playing games. In all of these circumstances, it's not worth the effort.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21520129
It depends on the person and their personality. This is why texting is flawed, because you can't tell that you've made the other person uncomfortable. In real life, you would notice, and either apologize, or simply not ask that sort of question again.

In general though, you learn through experience and through a gentle pushing of the boundaries and listening to what the other person says. For instance, you probably shouldn't swear in front of someone until you've heard them swear. It also helps to pay attention to what they ask you about, so you can ask the same sorts of questions back. With time, you'll make small mistakes rather than big ones and figure out that particular person's boundaries.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21520129
If you want to broach a sensitive topic you trickle. You don't start with a direct question, just with an assertion ("hey I heard about your dad"), then they can deflect/dodge/dismiss (from "oh" and nothing more to "oh yeah shit sucks ha well we do the best we can anyway-") or they can engage you by telling a little, asking what you heard, mentioning their feelings, you name it.

General signs someone does not want to continue the chat and/or topic;
>convo-killers like "ah well", "it is what it is", "ANYWAY" said in a definitive way
>turning their feet/body away from you
>a lack of eye contact or only very briefly and rarely meeting your gaze, seeming distracted
>one word answers, basically providing nothing to the conversation
>getting out their phone, looking at their watch, mentioning being short on time or tired
>sighing, dragging or scraping their feet, nervous tics

Look for patterns. A single one of these (like avoiding direct eye contact) can still be related to just talking about sensitive stuff. For me the most telling is the combination of you needing to do all the work + a lack of eye contact. If someone is very emotional they might not be able to say much while wanting to talk, but they will still look at you, turn their body towards you, maybe even touch you. If they contribute nothing and their body language and face suggests being elsewhere, not good.

If REALLY in doubt just break the fourth wall.
>I hope you don't mind me bringing this up
>it's hard finding the words to do justice to this
>please tell me if I'm being intrusive

As someone relatively experienced with people who are grieving or in trouble, I can assure you that people avoiding the topic and not saying anything out of awkwardness is to 99/100 people more hurtful than broaching it with the best intentions and stumbling along.
